In C, MPI_Count can be ambiguous:
- MPI_Count is a datatype that is able to contain an address location in memory, an address offset in a file or just a count. The fact that the majority of MPI routines still rely on "int" count arguments is due to backward compatibility reasons.
- MPI_COUNT is an MPI_Datatype used to inform MPI about the type of a variable passed to a routine. Similar to MPI_INT being the MPI_Datatype corresponding to an int, MPI_COUNT is the MPI_Datatype corresponding to an MPI_Count. Please refer to MPI_COUNT_KIND to see the FORTRAN equivalent.

MPI_COUNT is an MPI_Datatype used to inform MPI about the type of a variable passed to a routine. Similar to MPI_INT being the MPI_Datatype corresponding to an int, MPI_COUNT is the MPI_Datatype corresponding to an MPI_Count.
(The distinction between MPI_Count and MPI_COUNT is only relevant in C.)
